solver package¶

Submodules¶

solver.derivatives module¶

solver.derivatives.derivative(f, x, order=1, dx=0.001)[source]¶

Calculates derivative of f of order order and evaluates it at point x

Parameters:
  • f (func) – a function that takes float and returns float
  • x (float) – point at which the derivative should be evaluated
  • order (0, 1, 2) – order of the derivative
  • dx (float) – difference used in calculation
Returns:

derivative of the function f evaluated at x
Return type:

float
solver.derivatives.numerov_taylor_series(f, y0, dy0, dx=0.001, x0=0)[source]¶

Uses Taylor series to approximate value:

y(x0 + dx) = y(x0) + y’(x0) * dx + …

assuming y is the solution of the equation of the form:

y”(x) = f(x) * y(x)

Parameters:
  • f (func) – a function that takes float and returns float
  • y0 (float) – value of y(x0)
  • dy0 (float) – value of y’(x0)
  • dx (float) – step size
  • x0 (float) – starting point at which values of y and y’ are known
Returns:

value of y(x0+dx)
Return type:

float

solver.gradient_descent module¶

solver.gradient_descent.gradient_descent(loss, x0=0, step=0.1, n_steps=10, dx=0.01)[source]¶

Calculates derivative of f of order order and evaluates it at point x

Parameters:
  • loss (func) – a function that takes float and returns float. Measures error that should be minimised
  • x0 (float) – point at which neighborhood we expect a minimum
  • step (float) – measure of step size. Scales gradient value
  • n_steps (int) – how many steps should be performed
Returns:

  • float – point representing an approximation of a local minimum in neighborhood of x0
  • float – loss value at that point

solver.numerov module¶

Implementation of various versions of Numerov’s method.

solver.numerov.ode_solve_numerov(f, y0, y1, x)[source]¶

Function solving second order ODEs using Numerov’s method.

The ODE should have the form: y”(x) = f(x) * y(x), y(x0) = y0, y(x1) = y1

Parameters:
  • f (func) – function that takes float and returns float being the value of f at this point
  • y0 (float) – value of y at x[0]
  • y1 (float) – value of y at x[1]
  • x (ndarray) – array (n,) where n is greater or equal 2. Should have the position values at which y should be calculated. The points should be distributed uniformly (between any two in a row, the distance should be the same).
Returns:

array (n,) where n is the length of x array, storing the values y(x)
Return type:

ndarray
solver.numerov.ode_solve_numerov_delta(f, y0, y1, x_max, delta)[source]¶

Function solving second order ODEs using Numerov’s method.

The ODE should have the form: y”(x) = f(x) * y(x), y(x0) = y0, y(x1) = y1

Parameters:
  • f (func) – function that takes float and returns float being the value of f at this point
  • y0 (float) – value of y at x[0]
  • y1 (float) – value of y at x[1]
  • x_max (float) – the interval will be [0, x_max)
  • delta (float) – spacing in the interval
Returns:

array (n,) storing the values y(x), where x is the interval [0, x_max) spaced by delta
Return type:

ndarray
Raises:

ValueError – if delta/x_max is too large and the interval does not have enough points

solver.rk module¶

solver.rk.ode_solve_rk(f, y0, t)[source]¶

Function solving first-order ODEs using Runge-Kutta method.

The ODE should have the form: y’(t) = f(y(t)), y(t0) = y0

Paweł Czyż, Date: 01/05/2018

Parameters:
  • f (func) – function that takes numpy array (k,) of coordinates and returns their derivatives as another array (k,)
  • y0 (ndarray) – ndarray (k,)
  • t (ndarray) – ndarray of shape (n,) with time points at which we want the value of function y
Returns:

array with shape (n, k) with solution
Return type:

ndarray
